Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: RAPID: How do extreme flooding events impact migratory species?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Extreme weather events can alter resources in dramatic ways, which can have positive, negative, or neutral impacts on species. In the case of hurricanes and tropical storms, heavy rains could trigger an unusual pulse of plant growth or, if extreme, drown critical resources. This substantial shift in resource availability almost certainly impacts the survival, reproduction, and growth of local populations; however, the extent to which migratory species are impacted is much less clear. Out-of-season resources may disrupt migration as individuals alter their normal behaviors, with potential negative consequences if arrival to winter or summer habitat is delayed or blocked. Alternatively, migratory species may avoid gaps in resources by shifting their routes, or even capitalize on resources that peak following heavy rainfall events, improving their survival at stopover locations and fitness at destination habitats. Texas is a critical migratory pathway in North America for many species of birds, bats, and insects and its position bordering the gulf coast means that it is also subject to many severe weather events during the tropical storm season. The recent flooding associated with Hurricane Harvey, the most extreme rainfall event in US history, provides a unique opportunity to investigate how plant resources shift in response to disruptive weather events. Further, hypotheses on the demographic responses of migratory species will be rigorously tested at both local and regional scales. This project will study the impact of Hurricane Harvey on a model migratory species, the eastern North American monarch butterfly (Danaus plexippus L.) population, with the goal of developing a framework to understand the impact of extreme flooding events on migratory species. The results will inform conservation efforts for the monarch butterfly, population models, and climate forecasting.

This research will examine the effects of Harvey on monarch dynamics in the local Texas migratory corridor and evaluate the potential for carry-over effects into the monarch's overwintering population in Mexico and summer breeding population in central and eastern North America. The project will accomplish this through three key activities. First, data will be collected at survey sites throughout the affected area during the fall, winter, and spring of the 2017-2018 migratory season. Second, the impact of Harvey and other recent extreme rainfall events will be explored using climate data and remotely-sensed satellite imagery to model vegetation growth. Finally, monarch population models will link local conditions in Texas to the overwintering population in Mexico, and subsequently to spring and summer generations. This research advances macrosystems ecology by expanding the spatiotemporal scale at which carry-over effects from resource disruptions may impact migratory species, and providing a framework for incorporating conditions experienced by animals during migratory periods (the least-studied stages of the annual cycle) into population models to evaluate mechanisms governing long-term trends.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Extreme weather events can alter available resources in dramatic ways, which can have positive, negative, or neutral impacts on organisms. In the case of hurricanes and tropical storms, heavy rains could trigger an unusual pulse of plant growth or, if extreme, drown critical resources. Out-of-season resources may disrupt migration as individuals alter their normal behaviors, with potential negative carryover consequences if arrival to their destination is delayed or blocked. Alternatively, migratory species may avoid gaps in resources lost to flooding by shifting their routes, or even capitalize on resources that peak following heavy rainfall events, improving their survival at stopover locations and fitness at destination habitats.

Texas is a critical migratory pathway in North America, with many species of birds, bats, and insects flying through on their way north to breeding grounds each spring and south to overwintering sites each fall. Flooding associated with Hurricane Harvey (during late summer 2017) provided a unique opportunity to investigate how plant resources shift in response to disruptive weather events and to rigorously test hypotheses on the demographic responses of migratory species. For this project, we evaluated the impacts of Hurricane Harvey on a model migratory species, the eastern North American monarch butterfly (Danaus plexippus) population, within and beyond the geographic extent of the storm. We examined the effects of Harvey on monarch dynamics in the local Texas migratory corridor and for carry-over effects into the monarch overwintering population in Mexico and summer breeding population in central and eastern North America and southern Canada. To do this, we collected new data on resources (milkweed for breeding and nectar sources critical to successful migration) and monarchs (eggs and adults) throughout the spring of 2018. We also leveraged data collected during the fall of 2017 immediately after Hurricane Harvey and later in 2019. We conducted resource modeling and climate hindcasting of previous extreme precipitation events and developed models of spring monarch populations by using auxiliary 'incidental sightings' monarch data.

We found an increase in vegetation green-up during the fall of 2017 immediately following Hurricane Harvey as well as increased monarch reproduction during that fall period (something that is generally thought to be negative for monarch population dynamics). However, our retrospective analyses showed that the amount of fall green-up did not fall outside normal, yearly variability. By spring 2018 (and afterwards), we found no effect of areas flooded by Harvey (e.g. weeks of standing water following the hurricane) compared to non-flooded sites on either plant growth, adult monarch abundance, or egg abundance. Monarchs naturally occur in low abundance in Texas and the surrounding region during the spring time. Milkweed is patchy in distribution and randomly selected sampling locations may not be effective at capturing milkweed responses to flooding as many sites do not contain milkweed. Our results will thus be helpful to inform the continued development of the Integrated Monarch Monitoring Protocol.

To examine how widespread our results may be, we conducted a broader review of the literature and found that most research suggests that migrants are generally able to avoid the most negative effects of Atlantic hurricanes. Research to date has generally focused on birds, but bats and insects also constitute a substantial portion of migrants each year. Insects in particular are likely to be influenced by the distribution of resources in their migratory pathway because most have multi-generational migrations (in contrast to vertebrate migrants) and thus are often breeding along their migratory routes. It is important to understand how well migrating species can adapt to hurricanes, especially as they increase in frequency and intensity with a changing climate. We note that these results do not apply to resident species which may be profoundly impacted by hurricanes and other regional disruptions. 

The results from this project were shared with management agencies, as the USFWS is currently considering whether the monarch butterfly should be listed under the Endangered Species Act, and with heads of citizen science organizations. Results from this work have also been incorporated into a larger, full annual cycle analysis of monarchs. Funding for this project supported two graduate students and two postdoctoral researchers at three institutions.
